qas.question: How high of a temperature change can glass-ceramics handle?
Because of their heat resistance, glass-ceramics are especially suitable for what?
What is the most economically significant property of glass-ceramics?
What ingredients give glass-ceramics its useful heat tolerance?
What proportion of crystalline ceramics yields a product with a CTE of around 0?
How high of a temperature change can CTEs handle?
Because of their heat resistance, arrays are especially suitable for what?
What is the most economically significant property of countertops?
What ingredients give glass-ceramics its useful thermal expansion?
What proportion of crystalline ceramics yields a product with a CTE of around 1000?

context: The term mainly refers to a mix of <a3_0><b8_0>lithium and aluminosilicates<b8_0/><a3_0/> that yields an array of materials with interesting thermomechanical properties. The most commercially important of these have the distinction of being <a2_0><b7_0>impervious to thermal shock<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Thus, glass-ceramics have become extremely useful for <a1_0><b6_0>countertop cooking<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The negative thermal expansion coefficient (CTE) of the crystalline ceramic phase can be balanced with the positive CTE of the glassy phase. At a certain point (<a4_0><b9_0>~70%<b9_0/><a4_0/> crystalline) the glass-ceramic has a net CTE near zero. This type of glass-ceramic exhibits excellent mechanical properties and can sustain repeated and quick temperature changes up to <a0_0><b5_0>1000 °C<b5_0/><a0_0/>.
